greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(2n)=2n, a(2n+1)=4n+1.
comment: Original definition (typos corrected):  The following triangle contains n consecutive numbers beginning from n in ascending order if n is odd else in descending order. 1 3 2 3 4 5 7 6 5 4 5 6 7 8 9 11 10 9 8 7 6 ... Sequence contains the leading diagonal.
The sequence satisfies a divisibility property described by E. Angelini on the SeqFan list, cf. link. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 22 2013
link: Harvey P. Dale, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
E. Angelini, k-chunks sum and division by k, post to the SeqFan list, Mar 22 2013
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,2,0,-1).
example: The triangle described in the original definition starts
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Nov 15 2005
ext: Simpler definition from _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 22 2013
